messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Optimal Coding Theorems in Time-Bounded Kolmogorov Complexity

Paper Abstract: Abstract The classical coding theorem in Kolmogorov complexity states that if an nğ‘›n-bit string xğ‘¥x is sampled with probability Î´ğ›¿\delta by an algorithm with prefix-free domain then ğ–ªâ€‹(x)â‰¤logâ¡(1/Î´)+Oâ€‹(1)ğ–ªğ‘¥1ğ›¿ğ‘‚1\mathsf{K}(x)\leq\log(1/\delta)+O(1). In a recent work, Lu and Oliveira [29] established an unconditional time-bounded version of this result, by showing that if xğ‘¥x can be efficiently sampled with probability Î´ğ›¿\delta then ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—â€‹(x)=Oâ€‹(logâ¡(1/Î´))+Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ‘¥ğ‘‚1ğ›¿ğ‘‚ğ‘›\mathsf{rKt}(x)=O(\log(1/\delta))+O(\log n), where ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—\mathsf{rKt} denotes the randomized analogue of Levinâ€™s ğ–ªğ—ğ–ªğ—\mathsf{Kt} complexity. Unfortunately, this result is often insufficient when transferring applications of the classical coding theorem to the time-bounded setting, as it achieves a Oâ€‹(logâ¡(1/Î´))ğ‘‚1ğ›¿O(\log(1/\delta)) bound instead of the information-theoretic optimal logâ¡(1/Î´)1ğ›¿\log(1/\delta). Motivated by this discrepancy, we investigate optimal coding theorems in the time-bounded setting. Our main contributions can be summarised as follows. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Efficient coding theorem for ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—\mathsf{rKt} with a factor of 222. Addressing a question from [29], we show that if xğ‘¥x can be efficiently sampled with probability at least Î´ğ›¿\delta then ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—â€‹(x)â‰¤(2+oâ€‹(1))â‹…logâ¡(1/Î´)+Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ‘¥â‹…2ğ‘œ11ğ›¿ğ‘‚ğ‘›\mathsf{rKt}(x)\leq(2+o(1))\cdot\log(1/\delta)+O\!\left(\log n\right). As in previous work, our coding theorem is efficient in the sense that it provides a polynomial-time probabilistic algorithm that, when given xğ‘¥x, the code of the sampler, and Î´ğ›¿\delta, it outputs, with probability â‰¥0.99absent0.99\geq 0.99, a probabilistic representation of xğ‘¥x that certifies this ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—\mathsf{rKt} complexity bound. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Optimality under a cryptographic assumption. Under a hypothesis about the security of cryptographic pseudorandom generators, we show that no efficient coding theorem can achieve a bound of the form ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—â€‹(x)â‰¤(2âˆ’oâ€‹(1))â‹…logâ¡(1/Î´)+ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’â€‹(logâ¡n)ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ‘¥â‹…2ğ‘œ11ğ›¿ğ—‰ğ—ˆğ—…ğ—’ğ‘›\mathsf{rKt}(x)\leq(2-o(1))\cdot\log(1/\delta)+\mathsf{poly}(\log n). Under a weaker assumption, we exhibit a gap between efficient coding theorems and existential coding theorems with near-optimal parameters. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Optimal coding theorem for ğ—‰ğ–ªtsuperscriptğ—‰ğ–ªğ‘¡\mathsf{pK}^{t} and unconditional Antunes-Fortnow. We consider ğ—‰ğ–ªtsuperscriptğ—‰ğ–ªğ‘¡\mathsf{pK}^{t} complexity [18], a variant of ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—ğ—‹ğ–ªğ—\mathsf{rKt} where the randomness is public and the time bound is fixed. We observe the existence of an optimal coding theorem for ğ—‰ğ–ªtsuperscriptğ—‰ğ–ªğ‘¡\mathsf{pK}^{t}, and employ this result to establish an unconditional version of a theorem of Antunes and Fortnow [2] which characterizes the worst-case running times of languages that are in average polynomial-time over all ğ–¯ğ–¯\mathsf{P}-samplable distributions.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The equivalence of sampling and searching",
        "Worst-case running times for average-case algorithms",
        "Using depth to capture average-case complexity",
        "Applications of time-bounded Kolmogorov complexity in complexity theory",
        "When worlds collide: Derandomization, lower bounds, and Kolmogorov complexity",
        "The complexity of complexity",
        "On the theory of average case complexity",
        "Resource-bounded Kolmogorov complexity revisited",
        "Language compression and pseudorandom generators",
        "Average-case complexity",
        "Universal almost optimal compression and Slepian-Wolf coding in probabilistic polynomial time",
        "Tight quantum time-space tradeoffs for function inversion",
        "Maximum flow and minimum-cost flow in almost-linear time",
        "Randomness conductors and constant-degree lossless expanders",
        "Time space tradeoffs for attacks against one-way functions and PRGs",
        "Rigorous time/space trade-offs for inverting functions",
        "Kolmogorov complexity and computational complexity",
        "Probabilistic Kolmogorov complexity with applications to average-case complexity",
        "Unbalanced expanders and randomness extractors from Parvaresh-Vardy codes",
        "Non-black-box worst-case to average-case reductions within NP",
        "Average-case hardness of NP from exponential worst-case hardness assumptions",
        "Expander graphs and their applications",
        "Efficiency improvements in constructing pseudorandom generators from one-way functions",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Information in propositional proofs and algorithmic proof search",
        "Kolmogorov complexity and formula lower bounds",
        "Randomness conservation inequalities; information and independence in mathematical theories",
        "Average case complete problems",
        "An efficient coding theorem via probabilistic representations and its applications",
        "Pseudodeterministic algorithms and the structure of probabilistic time",
        "On one-way functions and Kolmogorov complexity",
        "Average case complexity under the universal distribution equals worst-case complexity",
        "An introduction to Kolmogorov complexity and its applications",
        "Navigating central path with electrical flows: From flows to matchings, and back",
        "Pseudorandom bits for constant depth circuits",
        "Randomness and intractability in Kolmogorov complexity",
        "Hardness of KT characterizes parallel cryptography",
        "Complexity theory column 89: The polynomial hierarchy, random oracles, and boolean circuits",
        "A complexity theoretic approach to randomness",
        "Improved pseudorandom generators from pseudorandom multi-switching lemmas",
        "Simple extractors for all min-entropies and a new pseudorandom generator",
        "Tight bounds on the fourier spectrum of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0{\\sf AC}^{0}",
        "Lossless condensers, unbalanced expanders, and extractors",
        "A derandomized switching lemma and an improved derandomization of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0{\\sf AC}^{0}",
        "Pseudorandomness",
        "A uniform min-max theorem with applications in cryptography"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Optimal Coding Theorems in Time-Bounded Kolmogorov Complexity, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
